history.content:
"INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Meet with your ESS Adviser to discuss your situation. Visit http://engineering.berkeley.edu/ess to make an appointment."

TA for both courses here. 106A/B focuses on a very different area of robotics than the ML/AI stuff, with topics like kinematics and dynamics of open chain manipulators as well as control, grasping, and a couple other special topics. It's highly physics-based, and IMO shares more with courses in the MechE department than almost anything in EECS.

106A covers chapters 2, 3, and a bit of 4 in this book: https://www.cds.caltech.edu/~murray/books/MLS/pdf/mls94-complete.pdf

106B covers chapters 4, 5, and 6 among other things.

Classes that would provide a useful background for 106B (in lieu of or in conjunction with 106A) are EE 128, ME 175, ME 136, ME 193B, and potentially EE 149 or 192 (I haven't taken either, but there's likely a little bit of overlap). 106B is a very difficult / time-intensive class, but is very rewarding if you push through.

Professor Sahai talks a lot about "mathematical maturity" in the context of 189, and I think many of the same arguments apply to 106B. If you have a very strong background in linear algebra and differential equations, as well as strong physical intuition and a good programming background, it's possible to take 106B without 106A. We get a number of grad students (mostly controls students in the MechE department) who do this successfully every spring. However, we've had very high drop rates every semester the class has been offered, even from students who did well in 106A, so if you choose to try it, watch out.

Any thoughts on taking CS 106B (Robotics) without the prerequisite 106A?

If there's a website or syllabus covering 106A someone can share that would be great. I'm willing to put in a little bit of time over winter break looking at any prereq material if necessary.

Just for context I have experience doing research in the software side of ML/AI but am thinking of getting involved in robotics domains.
history.subject: CS 106B without prereq
